metadata.title: Recent developments in the sonoelectrochemical synthesis of nanomaterials

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Ultrasonics - Sonochemistry

Recent developments in the sonoelectrochemical synthesis of nanomaterials
Md Hujjatul Islama,⁎, Michael T.Y. Paulb, Odne S. Burheima, Bruno G. Polleta
aHydrogen Energy and Sonochemistry Research Group, Department of Energy and Process Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), NO-7491 Trondheim, Norway bDepartment of Chemistry, Simon Fraser University, 8888 University Drive, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanoparticles Nanocomposites Nanomaterials Power ultrasound Sonoelectrochemistry
A B S T R A C T
In recent years, the synthesis and use of nanoparticles have been of special interest among the scientific communities due to their unique properties and applications in various advanced technologies. The production of these materials at industrial scale can be difficult to achieve due to high cost, intense labour and use of hazardous solvents that are often required by traditional chemical synthetic methods. Sonoelectrochemistry is a hybrid technique that combines ultrasound and electrochemistry in a specially designed electrochemical setup. This technique can be used to produce nanomaterials with controlled sizes and shapes. The production of nanoparticles by sonoelectrochemistry as a technique offers many advantages: (i) a great enhancement in mass transport near the electrode, thereby altering the rate, and sometimes the mechanism of the electrochemical reactions, (ii) a modification of surface morphology through cavitation jets at the electrode-electrolyte interface, usually causing an increase of the surface area and (iii) a thinning of the electrode diffusion layer thickness and therefore ion depletion. The scalability of sonoelectrochemistry for producing nanomaterials at industrial scale is also very plausible due to its “one-pot” synthetic approach. Recent advancements in sonoelectrochemistry for producing various types of nanomaterials are briefly reviewed in this article. It is with hope that the presentation of these studies therein can generate more interest in the field to “catalyze” future investigations in novel nanomaterial development and industrial scale-up studies.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
According to the International Union of Pure Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) definitions, nanoparticles are classified by a critical diameter of less than 100 nm [1]. This class of materials has an important role in many different fields due to their unique characteristics that are not observed in their bulk counterparts [2,3]. The surface area to volume (A:V) ratios of these materials can be greatly enhanced by reducing the particle sizes. This increase in surface area is especially important in catalysis applications, where a majority of the reaction relies upon the interaction between the reagents and the surfaces of the catalysts. There is a number of chemical and physical methods that have been proposed to prepare nanomaterials including alcohol reduction, citrate reduction, polyol reduction, borohydride reduction, photolytic reduction, radiolytic reduction, laser ablation, and metal evaporation condensation, to name but a few [4–12]. Generally, the controlled synthesis of nanoparticles is often performed by chemical methods where the size, shape, and composition of these particles can be finely tuned to tailor to a specific catalytic activity [4,5]. Chemical methods such as
hydrothermal sol-gel can, however, involve high temperatures, organic solvents, and multiple purification processes that are more difficult to implement at industrial scale [6,7]. Some improvements in the production methods also include the use of microwaves, magnetic heating, and UV-reactors to increase the scalability of these chemical syntheses [8–12]. However, the size distribution of the nanoparticles produced by microwaves is relatively broad [12]. Magnetic and UV-reactions are also limited to specific reactions only, in effect, magnetic nanoparticles and UV-absorbing nanoparticle precursors [12,13]. Another approach to produce nanomaterials is to combine ultrasound with electrochemistry i.e. the use of sonoelectrochemistry.
Sonoelectrochemistry involves the use of an ultrasonic probe or bath in an electrochemical cell. The ultrasonic source can be used as the working electrode (WE) to electrochemically reduce ionic materials directly from the electroanalyte (Fig. 1). In most cases, the tip of the ultrasonic horn is used as the vibrating working electrode (also known as “sonoelectrode”) in a three-electrode setup [14–17]. In this configuration, a counter electrode (CE) and a reference electrode (RE) are placed very close to the vibrating WE. In the case of the production of

metallic nanoparticles, the sonoelectrode exposes only the flat circular area at the end of the ultrasonic tip to the electrodeposition solution (Fig. 1). The exposed area acts as both cathode and ultrasonic source. A short pulse of electrolysis current reduces many metallic ions at the cathode, forming a high density of fine metal nuclei. This short electrodeposition current pulse is immediately followed by a burst of ultrasonic energy that removes the metal nanoparticles from the cathode, cleans the surface of the cathode, and replenishes the double layer with metallic ions by efficient stirring of the solution. By tuning the electrolysis current, acoustic power and current/ultrasound time pulses, nanoparticles of various size and morphologies can be produced. Thus theoretically, the synthesis of nanomaterials by sonoelectrochemistry can achieve higher yields than those methods that require redox chemicals, where the applied galvanostatic current is related to the amount or concentration of the metallic salts (according toFaraday's Law) [4,5,18–31]. This method has been demonstrated in the literature to produce a wide range of nanoparticles including metals, metal-oxides, as well as supported nanoparticles [18–31].
As nanomaterials are becoming high demand products for use in many advanced applications, the sonoelectrochemistry method may also be scalable to produce these nanomaterials at industrial relevant quantities. Therefore, the objective of this paper is to provide a brief overview of recent advancements in sonoelectrochemistry for producing various types of nanomaterials. It is hoped that the review of these studies will generate more interest in the field, to fuel additional investigations of novel nanomaterials as well as propelling this technology in becoming a commercially viable synthetic technique.

sections.heading: 2. Power ultrasound and sonoelectrochemistry
sections.text:
By definition, ultrasonication is the application of vibrational energy to agitate aqueous suspensions with a frequency of> 20 kHz [32,33]. Historically, ultrasonication has been commonly used in the food and medical industry for the homogenization and emulsification of biological materials such as proteins and lipids [34]. The hydrodynamic shock waves produced by the ultrasonic device are able to disrupt the lipid bilayers of cell membranes. This homogenization effect of the ultrasonicator can be employed for sterilizing foodstuff [35]. For chemical applications, the “homogenization power” of the ultrasonicator has been used for achieving uniform agitation of chemicals that is more efficient than the use of a magnetic stirring bar or a high-shear mixer [32,36]. The ultrasonic irradiation can also result in the sonolysis of water, which can produce powerful radical species (OH% and H%) and highly localized heating [36–39]. The localized effect is the result of the oscillating compression and rarefaction of the aqueous medium [29,36,40]. The oscillation of the medium leads to the formation and implosion of intense cavitation bubbles [41]. The violent collapse of the these gas-filled cavitation bubbles can yield localized heating and atomization of the aqueous medium.
Sonoelectrochemistry is the use of power ultrasound in an electrochemical cell [42]. It was first introduced by Moriguchi in the 1930’s [43]. Ultrasonic irradiation not only affects heterogeneous systems involving electrode and electrolyte but also homogenous systems in the bulk solution [44,45]. The bulk solution experiences extreme conditions caused by acoustic cavitation which may give rise to new electrochemical reaction mechanisms [46]. Ultrasonic irradiation in an electrochemical cell can impart some specific benefits such as: solution and electrode degassing, thinning of the Nernst diffusion layer thickness (δ) and enhancement of mass transfer of electroactive species from the bulk solution to the electrode surface through the double layer [42]. These effects are mainly caused by acoustic cavitation and micro/ macro-streaming i.e. the generation, growth and collapse of microbubbles in the electrolyte and by intense agitation [18,47]. When ultrasonic cavitation takes place near the electrode surface, jets of liquid caused by the implosion of cavitation bubbles hit the electrode perpendicular to its surface (Fig. 3). These liquid microjets can have speeds up to 200m/s [42,48,49]. All these phenomena contribute to the decrease in the Nernst diffusion layer thickness, the improvement of the overall mass transport, faster reaction rates, and efficient cleaning and degassing of the electrode surface. Mass transport rate enhancement is mainly caused by the turbulent flows created by the movement of acoustic cavitation bubbles.

sections.heading: 3.1. Metallic nanoparticles
sections.text:
As previously mentioned, nanoparticles are a special class of materials due to their enhanced surface area to volume ratio [29]. Metallic nanoparticles have attracted extensive interests in the different fields due to their distinct physicochemical catalytic properties. These intrinsic properties can be adjusted by controlling the crystallinity, size, and shape of the nanoparticles.
The first report on the use of ultrasound for the fabrication of metallic nanoparticles was in 1987 by the work of Gutierrez et al. [50] followed by the work of Nagata et al. [51] in 1992 who studied the reduction of Ag+ in solution. In 1995, Cao et al. [39] pioneered the reduction of iron pentacarbonyl into Fe nanoparticles by ultrasonic irradiation without the use of any reducing agents [39]. However, the production of nanoparticles that relies solely upon ultrasonically produced radicals can be somewhat inefficient due to the high reduction potential of certain metal particles [52]. Therefore, the hybrid method of electrochemical deposition and ultrasonication has been successfully demonstrated for producing metallic nanomaterials in a simple and
controlled manner [14,53]. Dissolved metal ions in the solution can be both thermally and electrochemically reduced into metallic nanoparticles. The agitation provided by the ultrasonic horn also ensures even mixing of the reagents, resulting in relatively small dimensions of the reduced nanoparticles, while maintaining a good particle dispersion for minimizing and even eliminating aggregation.
Reisse et al. [54] were the first to introduce sonoelectrochemistry in metallic nanoparticle synthesis and copper was synthesized through this technique. After that, significant efforts have been made to produce many other different metallic nanoparticles, for example, cobalt, iron, nickel, silver, magnesium, aluminum, lead, cadmium, gold and tungsten, to name but a few [55].
Zhu et al. [56] attempted to synthesize shape-controlled silver (Ag) nanoparticles through the pulsed sonoelectrochemical method from an aqueous silver nitrate (AgNO3) solution in the presence of nitrilotriacetate N(CH2COOH)3-NTA. A titanium ultrasonic horn acted both as the ultrasound emitter and the cathode. This sonoelectrode produced current pulses (tI = 0.5 s) which were immediately followed by ultrasonic pulses (tus= 0.3 s). The acoustic intensity was 60W/cm2 and the current amplitude was 50mA/cm2. Various shapes of nanoparticles such as spherical nanoparticles, nanorods, and dendrites were obtained. The main influential factor was found to be the concentrations of AgNO3 and NTA which played a key role in the formation of differently shaped nanoparticles.
Stabilizer-free gold (Au) nanoparticles were synthesized by Shen et al. [57] by the pulsed sonoelectrochemical method. 24.3 mM of hydrogen tetrachloroaurate tetrahydrate (HAuCl4·4H2O) in 0.1M KNO3 solution was used as the electrolyte. 0.1M NaOH solution was used to adjust the pH. The current density was 16.3 mA/cm2 and the ultrasonic power was 20W (provided by a 20 kHz ultrasonic horn). They found that the current density, reaction time and pH influenced the size and shape of the Au nanoparticles which could be tuned by controlling those parameters.
Liu et al. [58] have also studied the size-controlled synthesis of gold (Au) nanoparticles of 2–15 nm sonoelectrochemically from the bulk gold substrate. In this method, a sheet of gold foil, platinum foil and Ag/AgCl was used as working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode respectively. The electrolyte was a 0.1 N HCl solution. The size of the nanoparticles increased from 2 to 15 nm with increasing cathodic potential from +0.2 V to +0.6 V vs. SCE. A summary of the synthesis of different metallic nanoparticles are tabulated in Table 1.
In the area of energy materials, the reduction of noble metal salts by the sonoelectrochemical method has been found to offer numerous benefits over conventional reduction methods where the use of chemical reducing agents is avoided and faster reaction rates are obtained [67]. One example is the use of sonoelectrochemically-produced PGM (Platinum Group Metal) such as platinum (Pt) nanoparticle in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs) and Proton Exchange Membrane Water Electrolysers (PEMWEs) [68,69]. The drastically increased surface areas of the Pt nanocatalysts is one of the key technologies for reducing Pt usage (and thus cost) within the PEMFC and PEMWE systems while maintaining adequate performance and durability [68]. An example of carbon supported Pt nanoparticles produced by sonoelectrochemistry for use as a PEMFC catalyst is demonstrated in Fig. 2. These sonoelectrochemically prepared nanoparticles were demonstrated to be between 9 and 100 nm in diameters [15–17].

Co-Ni, Fe-Ni and Fe-Co alloy nanoparticles with a mean diameter of 1̴00 nm were synthesized by Delplancke et al. [54]. The hydrothermal synthesis of QDs involved tuning the temperature, reaction duration, and composition of the reagents. This QD method often requires hours of preparation and it was found that the sonoelectrochemical approach could significantly reduce the synthesis time. In 2013, Shi et al. [25] presented a facile one-pot synthesis technique by sonoelectrochemistry. A schematic representation of this method is illustrated in Fig. 4. It was found that the sonoelectrochemical parameters such as the current pulse can be used to control the sizes of the QDs. The quantum yields and photoluminescence of these sonoelectrochemically produced QDs were shown to be comparable to those produced with the hydrothermal method.
Bimetallic alloys of Ni and Cu were also reported with some applications in biosensing that exhibited higher resistance to corrosion [70]. Zin et al. [24] demonstrated the use of sonoelectrochemistry for the successful production of Ni-Cu of uniform sizes (~100 nm). It was suggested that the sonoelectrochemical production can result in a
higher yield than other traditional chemical reduction techniques. To obtain alloy nanoparticles, a fast reduction rate of the metal ions is required. However, the increased reductive conditions can lead to an increase in particle size. A slower reduction rate may also lead to the production of non-alloy nanoparticles. Because the electrochemical reduction of these alloy particles occurs at a relatively high reduction potential, a higher percentage of alloy particles can be produced, while maintaining small particle sizes. Compared to a typical synthesis of NiCu alloy nanoparticles where the particle sizes are> 20 nm, the sonoelectrochemical synthesis method resulted in average particles sizes of ~9 nm [70,71].
In addition to alloy nanoparticles, there are several semiconductor materials that have been produced by the sonoelectrochemical method such as Bi2Te3, Sb2Te3, Bi2Se3, Cu2O, CdSe, PbTe, MoS2, CdTe, and TiO2 [67]. For example, Qui et al. [72] studied the sonoelectrochemical synthesis of Bi2Se3 nanowires of 10–40 nm diameters. In this method, an aqueous solution of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O and Na2SeSO3 in the presence of nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) was used as precursors. The solution was sonicated for 1–3 h in the absence and presence of an electrical current using a 0.6 cm diameter sonotrode operating at 20 kHz. The best-crystallized products were obtained in the range of current densities of 35.4–53mA/cm2. TEM study showed that it is possible to obtain a nanowire junction with a sharp interface just after 15min of reaction time and multi-junction nanowires were found in longer sonicated samples (See Fig. 5) [79].
Qiu et al. [73] reported the synthesis of highly uniform, singlecrystalline and pure PbTe nanorods through the pulsed sonoelectrochemical method using NTA as a stabilizer. The process included two steps where electrodeposition of PbTe on Ti sonotrode was performed in the first step followed by the dispersion of the PbTe nuclei into the solution by pulse sonication in the second step. The ratio between Pb2+/NTA played a vital role in the formation of PbTe nanorods where the lower concentration of Pb2+ provided only spherical particles and higher concentrations yielded rod-shaped morphologies.
Cu2O nanopowders were synthesized by Mancier et al. [74] in potentiostatic mode using a three-electrode setup using a working sonoelectrode. It was found through XRD analyses that in the applied potential range of −0.65 and −1.0 V vs. SSE (Saturated mercury Sulfate Electrode), only Cu2O was formed. TEM analyses showed that the nanopowders consisted of both agglomerates of grains and isolated particles with a mean diameter of 8 nm.
CdSe nanoparticles of the tubular structure were synthesized by Shen et al. [75] at a constant current density of 60–80mA/cm2 in the
presence of continuous sonication. It was proposed that the nanotubes were formed through a roll-up mechanism with an outer diameter of 80 nm and a wall thickness of 10 nm induced by ultrasonication. At first, the 2D nanosheets were formed on the electrode surface. These nanosheets were then removed from the electrode by ultrasonication. The nanosheets carried high surface energy at the edges, which then roll-up to form the tubular shape.
Mohapatra et al. [76] synthesized self-ordered arrays of TiO2 nanotubes of 30–100 nm in diameter and 300–1000 nm in length with 5–20 V of applied cell voltage. Ultrasound was used to enhance the mobility of the ionic species in the solution. TiO2 nanotubes were formed by the anodization of the titanium (Ti) foils in ethylene glycol solution using ultrasonic irradiation of 42 kHz (100W). The formation rate of TiO2 nanotubes using the sonoelectrochemical method was almost twice as fast as the magnetic stirring method. It was proposed that the collapsing of cavitation bubble at the solid surface forming microjets increased the mass flow through the nanotube surface, which increased the formation of nanotubes. It was also found that the photocatalytic activity of the TiO2 nanotubes formed by sonoelectrochemical method was higher than for the nanotubes prepared by the magnetic stirring method [76].
Fullerene-like MoS2 nanoparticle was synthesized by Mastai et al. [17] at room temperature through pulsed sonoelectrochemical method using 50mM ammonium tetrathiomolybdate [(NH4)2MoS4] and 1M sodium sulfate [NaSO4] at pH of 6.0. A constant deposition current of 160mA/cm2 and an acoustic power of 16W (20 kHz) was applied with “on and off” times of 0.34 s for both current and ultrasound. The sizes of the obtained nanoparticles were of several tens of nm with the same order of magnitude in all three dimensions. Normally, high temperature is required to obtain such closed fullerene-like nanoparticles, but thanks to the combination of power ultrasound and electrochemistry, it was possible to overcome the high-temperature requirements [17].
There are a few studies and examples of sonoelectrochemical production of alloy and semiconductor nanoparticles, but it was found that molybdenum sulfide (MoS2), Eu2O3 and Tb2O3, and lead selenide (PbSe) nanoparticles can be successfully prepared [67].

sections.heading: 3.3. Polymeric nanoparticles
sections.text:
Polymeric nanoparticles especially conducting polymers are interesting due to their remarkable properties and applications in different areas, e.g. in sensors, energy storage devices, conducting paints and surface treatment and protections [77,78]. Some examples of
conducting polymer nanomaterials are polyacetylene, polypyrrole, polythiophene, polyaniline, and their derivatives. These materials can be synthesized by using both chemical and electrochemical routes [78]. Powdery nanomaterials are normally synthesized through chemical reactions and nano-structure of conducting polymers are deposited onto the surface of the electrode through electropolymerization. Sonoelectrochemistry can facilitate the synthesis of size and shape-controlled conducting polymers.
Electrodeposition of polythiophene was carried out by Reyman et al. [79] in an acetonitrile solution in the presence of 530 kHz transducer mounted onto a stainless steel plate. The electrodeposited surface of polythiophene was found to be more compact and homogeneous in the presence of ultrasound than in its absence. This result was obtained due to two parallel phenomena. The first was the enhanced diffusion of the electroactive species to the electrode surface caused by ultrasonic stirring. The second phenomenon was the direct physical effects of ultrasound forming liquid microflows close to the electrode surface. In addition, the microbubbles eliminated points with the greatest energy on the electrode surface which helped to form a clean and homogenous surface.
Polyaniline (PA) nanoparticles were first synthesized by Ganesan et al. [80] using pulsed sonoelectrochemistry where the working electrode acted as both the cathode and the ultrasonic emitter. In this process, a constant potential pulse of +1V vs. Ag/AgCl was applied in a 0.5 M aniline and 0.5M HCl solution for 2 h. The applied ultrasonic power was 76W. The obtained nanomaterials had a diameter of 2–4 μm and an average size of 20–40 nm. The smaller size polyaniline nanoparticles were obtained due to the sonoelectro-pulse, which promoted the nucleation and removal of polyaniline nanoparticles from the sonoelectrode surface.
One of the most widely studied conducting polymer is polypyrrole due to its high electroconductivity, very good stability and facile synthesis method through chemical or electrochemical polymerization. Dejeu et al. [81] synthesized polypyrrole films using high-frequency ultrasound (500 kHz) where electrochemical polymerization of polypyrrole was possible on the silicon substrate. It was found that ultrasonication helped to reduce the roughness of the film and increase the homogeneity of the surface. The adhesion properties of polypyrrole film were found to be very weak indicating the suitable application of this materials in robotics since it is necessary to minimize the adhesion force between the micro-objects and the gripper through micro-manipulations.
Poly(N-methylaniline) (PNMA) conducting polymer was prepared by Atobe et al. [82] using the pulsed sonoelectrochemical method. A constant potential of 0.75 V vs. SCE (Saturated Calomel Electrode) was provided through a platinum electrode in an aqueous solution of methylaniline in HClO4. The ultrasonic intensity was 31W/cm−2 with a duration pulse of 5 s. Mainly ultrasound contributed in ablating the PNMA microspheres from the anode surface without any destruction of the microsphere. It was also found that the effective removal of the deposited PNMA from the anode surface by the ultrasonic pulse before the next electric pulse prevented further growth of the spheres.

sections.heading: 3.4. Nanocomposites
sections.text:
Nanocomposites are composite materials that incorporate nanoparticles into a matrix of standard materials. Incorporation of nanoparticles into a matrix drastically improves the mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of the composites. The number of nanoparticles that are normally added into the matrix is usually in the range of 0.5–5 % by weight. These nanocomposite materials have various applications e.g. in biomedicine, electronics, optics, electrochemical energy conversion and storage and solar energy [83]. However, it is necessary to choose the right nanoparticles and develop the right approaches to assemble them in order to obtain targeted functional nanocomposites. Therefore, it is crucial to study the possible efficient routes to produce
nanocomposites. Sonoelectrochemistry could be an attractive method to synthesize functional nanoparticles of targeted properties [67].
For example, Wang et al. [84] studied the synthesis of TiO2 nanotube by incorporating CdS nanoparticles through a single-step sonoelectrodeposition method. TiO2 nanotube arrays were used as the working electrode and platinum foil was used as the counter electrode. A mixture of 0.01M CdCl2 in dimethyl sulfoxide with elemental sulfur saturation was used as the electrolyte. The mixture was then degassed with N2 and stirred followed by ultrasonic irradiation using a 40 kHz ultrasonic transducer transmitting 2.4 kW/m2 ultrasonic intensity. After that, CdS was cathodically electrodeposited at a current density of 0.5 mA/cm2. The use of ultrasound in the CdS electrochemical deposition onto TiO2 provided better solar light harvest both in the UV and in the visible light.
Han et al. [85] have studied the sonoelectrochemical deposition of calcium phosphate on carbon fabrics. It was found that ultrasonic irradiation promoted smaller crystals growth on the substrate compared to simple electrodeposition. The incorporation of ultrasound also enabled better adhesive strength between the coating and substrate compared to silent conditions (in the absence of ultrasound). This effect was obtained due to the removal of generated hydrogen (H2) gas by ultrasonication from the substrate which increased the adhesion between the calcium phosphate and the carbon fabric.
Polypyrrole/multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)/chitosan nanocomposites were fabricated sonoelectrochemically for the first time by Ashassi-Sorkhabi et al. [86] for the purpose of corrosion prevention on St-12 steel using the galvanostatic method. The coating was carried out in a solution of oxalic acid (0.1M), pyrrole monomer (0.1M), chitosan (0.02 g/l), dodecylbenzene sulfonic acid (100mg/l) and MWCNTs (0.05 g/l) under ultrasonic irradiation. The electrochemical cell was comprised of a working and a counter electrode as stainless steel 12 and platinum respectively where a saturated calomel electrode was used as a reference electrode. The ultrasonic device was a 25 kHz ultrasonic probe. The corrosion protection properties of the coated material onto the steel was investigated using a 3.5% NaCl solution through the open circuit potential (OCP), potentiodynamic polarization and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy techniques. It was found that PPy-MWCNTs-chitosan composite coating provided better corrosion protection than PPy, PPy-chitosan and PPy/MWCNTs. The coated film acted as a strong physical barrier against corrosive materials due to the very dense and compact structure formed thanks to ultrasonic irradiation [86].
Zhang et al. [28] have studied a simple, fast, reproducible and efficient one-step process for the fabrication of gold nanoparticles/carbon nanosheet (Au NP/CNS) composites through the sonoelectrochemical method. Simultaneous synthesis of carbon nanosheet (CN) through oxidation of graphene anode and Au NPs by reducing AuCl4− on the cathode was carried out in this method. After that, the poly-diallyl dimethyl ammonium chloride modified Au NPs were self-assembled on the carbon nanosheet surface. Both the ultrasonic and electric fields affected the size and distribution of the Au NPs onto the CN surface.
Shi et al. [87] investigated the sonoelectrochemical synthesis of polydiallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA)- reduced Graphene Oxide (rGO)- PdPt nanocomposites. The co-electrodeposition of Pd with Pt was carried out at different atomic ratios. Then, the resulting alloy was incorporated with rGO in the presence of PDDA. It was observed that the dispersion of PdPt alloy nanoparticles onto the rGO was uniform with a mean particle size of 4.5 nm.

sections.heading: 4. Parameters influencing the sonoelectrochemical synthesis of nanoparticles
sections.text:
Considering the particle size and process efficiency, there are many experimental parameters that influence nanoparticle synthesis through sonoelectrochemistry. The main parameters are: the electroanalyte temperature, ultrasonic frequency, ultrasonic power, ultrasonic
intensity, current density, current pulse time (ton), ultrasonic pulse time (tus), the presence and absence of stabilizers and contamination from the ultrasonic horn. At low temperature, the nanocrystal growth is slower which results in finer crystal size. However, at a higher temperature, the yield is low due to the re-dissolution of the crystals [88]. Current density has a great influence on the final products. Lower current density allows more time for atomic diffusion promoting larger crystal growth. For example, for the synthesis of CdSe, the crystal size was found to be 10 nm at 100mA/cm2 whereas at 250mA/cm2 the crystal size was 5 nm [89]. On the other hand, particle size variation from 29 to 10 nm was observed when the current density increased from 55 to 110mA/cm2 for copper nanoparticle synthesis [59]. Higher current density also affects the yield of the process as secondary reactions may occur which decrease the yield of nanoparticles. For example, in the production of Co65Fe35 alloy nanoparticles, 50% cathodic efficiency was obtained at −20mA but the efficiency decreased by 10-fold once the applied current was increased by 50-fold. This is due to the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) occurring on the sonoelectrode at higher current density [90].
Another influential factor is the current pulse time. Producing nanoparticles sonoelectrochemically require the removal of deposits during the period of each ultrasonic pulse so that new nuclei can form during the current pulse time. Longer ton leads to the formation of larger crystal size and shorter ton promotes smaller crystal size. In addition, shorter current pulse times also increase the yield [90]. However, in the case of Pt and Cu2O nanoparticle synthesis, not a significant influence of the current pulse duration was observed [61,74]. The ultrasonic intensity should be high enough to remove the deposited nanoparticles from the sonoelectrode but should not be too high that might lead to energy losses. The ultrasonic pulse also affects the morphology and size of the nanoparticles where ultrafine particles experience high-velocity collision due to rapid particle movement resulting in agglomeration [91,92].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and future directions
sections.text:
Recent advancements in sonoelectrochemistry have shown that the preparation of complex nanomaterials is possible; these include bimetallic alloys, core-shell structures, supported nanoparticles, and 2D carbon-based materials. The shape, size, and morphology of the obtained nanoparticles can be tuned by adjusting the operating parameters such as ultrasonic power, applied current and electrode potential, ultrasonication and current pulse time, pH, temperature and electrolyte compositions. Most of the studies have also employed a “one-pot” approach to the sonoelectrochemical preparation of these nanoparticles.
A considerable amount of progress in this field has been attained but it is still in the initial stages for nanoparticle synthesis development. Sonoelectrochemical equipment for industrial scale is still relatively uncommon whereas lab-scale devices are commercially available. It is also extremely important to design the sonoelectrochemical reactor by taking advantage of both the sonochemical and sonophysical effects of ultrasound. In this case, the position of the ultrasonic probe (and sonoelectrode) and the coupling liquid play major roles in designing the setup. Moreover, ultrasonication in the electrochemical system provides significant benefits over simple electrochemical processes. It is hopeful that this simple, yet highly tunable technique can be adapted for use in an industrial setting. The use of this adaptable technique can further reduce the cost of nanomaterials production that is currently the bottleneck of some advanced technologies such as energy storage devices. Therefore, further advancement of sonoelectrochemical investigations can both enrich the scientific community as well as provide solutions for streamlining industrial processes.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, the synthesis and use of nanoparticles have been of special interest among the scientific communities due to their unique properties and applications in various advanced technologies. The production of these materials at industrial scale can be difficult to achieve due to high cost, intense labour and use of hazardous solvents that are often required by traditional chemical synthetic methods. Sonoelectrochemistry is a hybrid technique that combines ultrasound and electrochemistry in a specially designed electrochemical setup. This technique can be used to produce nanomaterials with controlled sizes and shapes. The production of nanoparticles by sonoelectrochemistry as a technique offers many advantages: (i) a great enhancement in mass transport near the electrode, thereby altering the rate, and sometimes the mechanism of the electrochemical reactions, (ii) a modification of surface morphology through cavitation jets at the electrode-electrolyte interface, usually causing an increase of the surface area and (iii) a thinning of the electrode diffusion layer thickness and therefore ion depletion. The scalability of sonoelectrochemistry for producing nanomaterials at industrial scale is also very plausible due to its “one-pot” synthetic approach. Recent advancements in sonoelectrochemistry for producing various types of nanomaterials are briefly reviewed in this article. It is with hope that the presentation of these studies therein can generate more interest in the field to “catalyze” future investigations in novel nanomaterial development and industrial scale-up studies.
